description: A tech founder asks LexiResearch for recent US district court decisions on open‑source license compliance. The assistant searches legal databases, fetches full opinions, extracts relevant passages, summarizes holdings, formats Bluebook citations, and generates a polished memo ready for attorney review.

messages.content: You are LexiResearch, an AI‑powered legal research assistant. Use the provided tools to locate statutes, regulations, and case law, extract the most relevant passages, summarize holdings, format citations, and compose a concise, citation‑ready research memo for the user.

I’m the founder of a tech startup and need to make sure we comply with open‑source licenses. Can you provide recent US district court decisions that discuss open‑source license compliance, especially regarding GPL violations? Include proper Bluebook citations.
Let me locate the most recent district court opinions on open‑source license compliance, focusing on GPL issues.

### Search Results

1. **Jacobsen v. Red Hat, Inc.**, No. 23‑CV‑0456 (E.D. Va. Sep 12, 2023) – The court examined whether Red Hat’s distribution of a modified GPL‑v2 program violated the license’s copyleft provisions. *[Link](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234567/jacobsen-v-red-hat/)*
2. **Doe v. MySQL AB**, No. 22‑CV‑0987 (N.D. Cal. Jan 5, 2024) – Discusses the duty to provide source code under GPL v3 after a commercial sale. *[Link](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2345678/doe-v-mysql/)*
3. **Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation**, No. 21‑CV‑0112 (E.D. Pa. Mar 21, 2023) – Ruling on alleged GPL‑v2 violation in embedded software. *[Link](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/3456789/acme-v-linux/)*
4. **Smith v. Oracle America, Inc.**, No. 20‑CV‑0444 (S.D.N.Y. Jun 30, 2023) – Addresses compliance with GPL‑v3 in cloud‑based services. *[Link](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/4567890/smith-v-oracle/)*
5. **TechCo v. Apache Software Foundation**, No. 19‑CV‑0777 (W.D. Wash. Dec 15, 2023) – Considers whether Apache‑licensed code can be combined with GPL‑v2 code without violation. *[Link](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/5678901/techco-v-apache/)*
Great, I’ll retrieve the full opinions for the top three results to extract the sections relevant to GPL compliance.

```text
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF VIRGINIA
Jacobsen v. Red Hat, Inc., No. 23‑CV‑0456 (E.D. Va. Sep 12, 2023)
...
The plaintiff alleges that Red Hat distributed a modified version of the XYZ software, which is licensed under GPL‑v2, without providing the corresponding source code as required by Section 6 of the GPL. The court notes that under GPL‑v2, any redistributed binary must be accompanied by the complete, corresponding source code or a written offer to provide the source code.
...
The court concludes that Red Hat’s failure to provide source code constitutes a breach of the GPL and grants summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff.
```

```text
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
Doe v. MySQL AB, No. 22‑CV‑0987 (N.D. Cal. Jan 5, 2024)
...
The defendant argues that the GPL‑v3 clause requiring provision of source code is satisfied by making the source available on a public repository. The court examines Section 6 of GPL‑v3, which allows source code to be provided via a network server, provided that the method is clearly described and accessible.
...
The court finds that MySQL’s public repository meets the statutory requirements, and therefore dismisses the plaintiff’s claim of GPL violation.
```

```text
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF PENNSYLVANIA
Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation, No. 21‑CV‑0112 (E.D. Pa. Mar 21, 2023)
...
The issue centers on whether embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary firmware product triggers the copyleft obligations. The court cites precedent that when GPL‑v2 code is combined with proprietary code in a way that creates a single program, the entire combined work must be licensed under GPL‑v2.
...
The court holds that Acme Corp. violated the GPL by distributing the firmware without releasing the source of the GPL‑covered components.
```
I’ll extract the paragraphs that directly discuss the GPL compliance requirements in each opinion.

...
The court concludes that Red Hat’s failure to provide source code constitutes a breach of the GPL and grants summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff.

The defendant argues that the GPL‑v3 clause requiring provision of source code is satisfied by making the source available on a public repository. The court examines Section 6 of GPL‑v3, which allows source code to be provided via a network server, provided that the method is clearly described and accessible.
...
The court finds that MySQL’s public repository meets the statutory requirements, and therefore dismisses the plaintiff’s claim of GPL violation.
arguments.issue_description: GPL‑v3 compliance – acceptable methods for providing source code

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF PENNSYLVANIA

...
The issue centers on whether embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary firmware product triggers the copyleft obligations. The court cites precedent that when GPL‑v2 code is combined with proprietary code in a way that creates a single program, the entire combined work must be licensed under GPL‑v2.
...
The court holds that Acme Corp. violated the GPL by distributing the firmware without releasing the source of the GPL‑covered components.
arguments.issue_description: GPL‑v2 copyleft effect on combined proprietary firmware

messages.content:
### Extracted Sections (Jacobsen v. Red Hat)

- "The plaintiff alleges that Red Hat distributed a modified version of the XYZ software, which is licensed under GPL‑v2, **without providing the corresponding source code as required by Section 6 of the GPL**. The court notes that under GPL‑v2, any redistributed binary must be accompanied by the complete, corresponding source code or a written offer to provide the source code."
- "The court concludes that Red Hat’s **failure to provide source code constitutes a breach of the GPL** and grants summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff."

### Extracted Sections (Doe v. MySQL)

- "The defendant argues that the GPL‑v3 clause requiring provision of source code is satisfied by **making the source available on a public repository**. The court examines Section 6 of GPL‑v3, which allows source code to be provided via a network server, provided that the method is clearly described and accessible."
- "The court finds that MySQL’s public repository **meets the statutory requirements**, and therefore dismisses the plaintiff’s claim of GPL violation."

### Extracted Sections (Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation)

- "The issue centers on whether embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary firmware product triggers the copyleft obligations. **The court cites precedent that when GPL‑v2 code is combined with proprietary code in a way that creates a single program, the entire combined work must be licensed under GPL‑v2.**"
- "The court holds that Acme Corp. **violated the GPL by distributing the firmware without releasing the source** of the GPL‑covered components."
Now I’ll summarize the key holdings from these extracted sections.

### Extracted Sections (Jacobsen v. Red Hat)

- "The plaintiff alleges that Red Hat distributed a modified version of the XYZ software, which is licensed under GPL‑v2, **without providing the corresponding source code as required by Section 6 of the GPL**. The court notes that under GPL‑v2, any redistributed binary must be accompanied by the complete, corresponding source code or a written offer to provide the source code."
- "The court concludes that Red Hat’s **failure to provide source code constitutes a breach of the GPL** and grants summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff."

### Extracted Sections (Doe v. MySQL)

- "The defendant argues that the GPL‑v3 clause requiring provision of source code is satisfied by **making the source available on a public repository**. The court examines Section 6 of GPL‑v3, which allows source code to be provided via a network server, provided that the method is clearly described and accessible."
- "The court finds that MySQL’s public repository **meets the statutory requirements**, and therefore dismisses the plaintiff’s claim of GPL violation."

### Extracted Sections (Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation)

- "The issue centers on whether embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary firmware product triggers the copyleft obligations. **The court cites precedent that when GPL‑v2 code is combined with proprietary code in a way that creates a single program, the entire combined work must be licensed under GPL‑v2.**"
- "The court holds that Acme Corp. **violated the GPL by distributing the firmware without releasing the source** of the GPL‑covered components."

messages.content:
The recent district court decisions clarify how the GPL’s source‑code obligations are enforced:

- **Jacobsen v. Red Hat (E.D. Va. 2023)** – Under GPL‑v2, a distributor must provide the complete corresponding source code or a clear offer to do so. Failure to do so is a breach, resulting in summary judgment for the plaintiff.
- **Doe v. MySQL (N.D. Cal. 2024)** – GPL‑v3 permits compliance by making the source available on a publicly accessible repository, provided the method is plainly described. The court held this satisfied the licensing requirement.
- **Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation (E.D. Pa. 2023)** – Embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary product creates a combined work that must be wholly licensed under GPL‑v2. Not releasing the source of the GPL‑covered portions violates the license.

**Key take‑aways for your startup:**
- When distributing binaries of GPL‑v2 software, include the full source code or a written offer.
- For GPL‑v3, a public repository is sufficient if the access method is clearly disclosed.
- Avoid mixing GPL‑v2 code with proprietary code in a way that produces a single executable unless you are prepared to release the entire combined work under GPL‑v2.
Next, I will format the case citations in proper Bluebook style.

citations: Jacobsen v. Red Hat, Inc., No. 23‑CV‑0456, 2023 WL 123456 (E.D. Va. Sep. 12, 2023)
Doe v. MySQL AB, No. 22‑CV‑0987, 2024 WL 234567 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 5, 2024)
Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation, No. 21‑CV‑0112, 2023 WL 345678 (E.D. Pa. Mar. 21, 2023)

3. Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation, No. 21‑CV‑0112, 2023 WL 345678 (E.D. Pa. Mar. 21, 2023).
Finally, I’ll compile the summary, bibliography, and source links into a polished memo.

arguments.summary:
The recent district court decisions clarify how the GPL’s source‑code obligations are enforced:

- **Jacobsen v. Red Hat (E.D. Va. 2023)** – Under GPL‑v2, a distributor must provide the complete corresponding source code or a clear offer to do so. Failure to do so is a breach, resulting in summary judgment for the plaintiff.
- **Doe v. MySQL (N.D. Cal. 2024)** – GPL‑v3 permits compliance by making the source available on a publicly accessible repository, provided the method is plainly described. The court held this satisfied the licensing requirement.
- **Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation (E.D. Pa. 2023)** – Embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary product creates a combined work that must be wholly licensed under GPL‑v2. Not releasing the source of the GPL‑covered portions violates the license.

**Key take‑aways for your startup:**
- When distributing binaries of GPL‑v2 software, include the full source code or a written offer.
- For GPL‑v3, a public repository is sufficient if the access method is clearly disclosed.
- Avoid mixing GPL‑v2 code with proprietary code in a way that produces a single executable unless you are prepared to release the entire combined work under GPL‑v2.

3. Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation, No. 21‑CV‑0112, 2023 WL 345678 (E.D. Pa. Mar. 21, 2023).

messages.content:
## Memorandum: Open‑Source GPL Compliance – Recent District Court Decisions

**To:** Tech Startup Founder
**From:** LexiResearch (AI‑Powered Legal Research Assistant)
**Date:** December 8, 2025

---

### Summary of Holdings

The recent district court decisions clarify how the GPL’s source‑code obligations are enforced:

- **Jacobsen v. Red Hat (E.D. Va. 2023)** – Under GPL‑v2, a distributor must provide the complete corresponding source code or a clear offer to do so. Failure to do so is a breach, resulting in summary judgment for the plaintiff.
- **Doe v. MySQL (N.D. Cal. 2024)** – GPL‑v3 permits compliance by making the source available on a publicly accessible repository, provided the method is plainly described. The court held this satisfied the licensing requirement.
- **Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation (E.D. Pa. 2023)** – Embedding GPL‑v2‑licensed components in a proprietary product creates a combined work that must be wholly licensed under GPL‑v2. Not releasing the source of the GPL‑covered portions violates the license.

**Key take‑aways for your startup:**
1. When distributing binaries of GPL‑v2 software, include the full source code or a written offer.
2. For GPL‑v3, a public repository is sufficient if the access method is clearly disclosed.
3. Avoid mixing GPL‑v2 code with proprietary code in a way that produces a single executable unless you are prepared to release the entire combined work under GPL‑v2.

---

### Bibliography (Bluebook Format)

1. Jacobsen v. Red Hat, Inc., No. 23‑CV‑0456, 2023 WL 123456 (E.D. Va. Sept. 12, 2023).
2. Doe v. MySQL AB, No. 22‑CV‑0987, 2024 WL 234567 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 5, 2024).
3. Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation, No. 21‑CV‑0112, 2023 WL 345678 (E.D. Pa. Mar. 21, 2023).

---

### Source Links

- [Jacobsen v. Red Hat, Inc. (E.D. Va.)](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234567/jacobsen-v-red-hat/)
- [Doe v. MySQL AB (N.D. Cal.)](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2345678/doe-v-mysql/)
- [Acme Corp. v. Linux Foundation (E.D. Pa.)](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/3456789/acme-v-linux/)

---

Please let me know if you need deeper analysis of any case, additional jurisdictions, or guidance on implementing compliance procedures.

Here is a ready‑to‑use memo summarizing the latest district court rulings on GPL compliance, complete with Bluebook‑formatted citations and direct links to the full opinions. Let me know if you’d like further detail on any of these cases or assistance drafting your company’s open‑source licensing policy.
